Headline.Para: Who Is the Real Atticus Finch? A lawsuit over 'To Kill a Mockingbird' on Broadway rekindles the conflict over an iconic literary figure: Champion of justice, or racist?

LeadPara.Para: One of the icons of American literature, Atticus Finch of "To Kill a Mockingbird," got a disconcerting revamp in 2015 when author Harper Lee published her long-lost first novel, "Go Set a Watchman." The crusading lawyer, who defends a wrongly accused black man in the beloved novel, appeared in a less heroic light in the earlier work. An adaptation of "To Kill a Mockingbird" is now planned for Broadway, but a lawsuit over it has rekindled the question: Which version of Atticus Finch is the right one?

TailParas.Para: Ms. Lee's estate argues that the planned stage version deviates too much from the novel. At the heart of the dispute is the play's depiction of Atticus, which seems to draw partly on the version of the character from "Watchman." According to the complaint, playwright Aaron Sorkin (best known for smart television dramas such as "The West Wing'' and "The Newsroom") portrays Atticus as an "apologist for the racial status quo" who is "rude," "selfish" and "naive." The lawsuit argues that, by contrast, the Atticus of "To Kill a Mockingbird" is "a model of wisdom, integrity, and professionalism," a figure "based on Ms. Lee's own father, a small-town Alabama lawyer who represented black defendants in a criminal trial."

It's true that Atticus was based on Harper Lee's father, A.C. Lee, and that her father, like Atticus, represented black defendants in a criminal trial. What the lawsuit doesn't say is that A.C. Lee also denounced civil-rights advocates as outsiders and campaigned for laws that would clamp down on black voter registration. He was, in short, the inspiration for both versions of Atticus—the champion of racial justice and the reactionary racist.

A deeper understanding of Harper Lee's father, and his daughter's struggle to come to terms with his legacy, sheds light not just on her fiction but on enduring tensions in Southern politics. How we view Atticus Finch also reveals a lot about how we view ourselves and our own relationship to the uncomfortable conflicts that first inspired Harper Lee to write. The play's producer, Scott Rudin, says that a more complex depiction of Atticus is necessary because "the world has changed." It may be more necessary because of the ways in which the world hasn't.

Like Atticus, A.C. Lee was a small-town lawyer and state legislator, but he was also partial owner and sole editor of the Monroe Journal, the local newspaper in Monroeville, Ala. From 1929 to 1947, he wrote hundreds of editorials, not just on local and state issues but on national and international developments. They reveal a man who took principled positions on vital matters of the day, including issues of racial injustice, but who also resented and actively opposed progressive movements that threatened to transform his native South.

In the 1930s, for example, A.C. Lee editorialized against mob violence that threatened the rule of law. His newspaper reported favorably on southern sheriffs and local officials who protected black prisoners from would-be lynchers.

Even more frequently he spoke out against political demagoguery, which was rampant in Depression-era Southern politics. No figure evoked his ire like Huey Long, the Louisiana populist whom Franklin Roosevelt famously described in 1932 as "one of the two most dangerous men in the country." (The other was Gen. Douglas MacArthur.) A.C. Lee decried Long's bullying of political opponents and the lies and half-truths that he used to manipulate the masses.

He remained loyal to Franklin Roosevelt long after most southern conservatives had abandoned the New Deal, despite what he and many other white southerners considered the undue influence on Roosevelt of labor and civil-rights radicals. Yet as much as A.C. Lee despised liberal Democrats, when war broke out in Europe, he hated even more that era's isolationist "America First" wing of the Republican Party, which opposed helping Britain in its darkest hour. When Roosevelt needed support for intervention in World War II, conservative white southerners in Congress were among his staunchest allies.

World War II changed practically everything in the American South, and the stresses showed up clearly on A.C. Lee's editorial page. Earnest and optimistic in the early and mid-1930s, he had turned jaundiced and cynical by the mid-1940s. His editorials from these years express many of the resentments that Atticus Finch voices in "Watchman"—anger over an expanding federal government, bitterness over a burgeoning civil-rights movement, and exasperation with a national Democratic Party that embraced both.

This was also when A.C. Lee and his independent-minded daughter—who in 1946 was the editor of the campus humor magazine at the University of Alabama—had their first public political argument. At issue was the Boswell Amendment, designed by Alabama's Jim Crow legislature to block African-Americans from registering to vote. The amendment gave local voting registrars the power to test applicants on their understanding of the U.S. Constitution. If they couldn't past the test, they couldn't register to vote.

A.C. Lee defended the amendment in a series of ponderous editorials on the importance of maintaining an educated and informed citizenry. They were distinguished from other pro-Boswell writings at the time in that he never mentioned the issue of race. Most supporters were rabidly explicit about the amendment's necessity in defending white supremacy. A Birmingham judge, for example, admitted some constitutional quibbles with the measure but considered them "a small price to pay…to keep this inferior, unreliable, irresponsible, easily corrupted race from destroying the highest civilization known to man."

Nelle Lee (as Harper was known at that time) skewered the Boswell Amendment in her publication. She wrote a precocious piece of political satire, a one-act play that presented a dimwitted racist demagogue who pushed the Boswell Amendment only to find himself later disenfranchised because he couldn't pass the test of constitutional knowledge. He appealed his case to the Supreme Court, which, upon hearing the man's complaint, responded: "Of all the cheek! How can the state of Alabama be so presumptuous as to require an ordinary voter to interpret the Constitution when we can't even interpret it ourselves?"

Controversy over the racial implications of voting requirements has not disappeared since Harper Lee's day, of course. Our own current debate about voter I.D. laws and restrictions on early voting and voting hours might seem a long way from the capricious tests administered by Jim Crow registrars, but Southern politics has a way of reaffirming that evergreen aphorism of William Faulkner's: "The past is never dead. It's not even past."

Regardless of how the dispute over the Broadway play is resolved in the courts, the answer to the question of which Atticus Finch is the right one—the noble hero of "Mockingbird" or the reactionary curmudgeon of "Watchman"—is simple. He is both of them.
Mr. Crespino is a professor of history at Emory University. His new book, "Atticus Finch: The Biography," will be published on May 8 by Basic Books.
